order.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: for the purpose of doing something
order.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Samuel trained every day in order to improve his performance.
In order to understand how the human body works, you need to have some knowledge of chemistry.
order.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: so that something can happen or so that someone can do something
order.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: Sunlight is needed in order for the process of photosynthesis to take place in plants.
order.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: the way that things or events are arranged in relation to each other, so that one thing is first, another thing is second etc
order.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: There seemed to be no logical order to the sections.
Make sure that you put the books back in the right order.
The files are all out of order.
out of order/in the wrong order
Their names are arranged in alphabetical order.
The cities are listed in order of importance.
Students learn the verbs in order of difficulty.
The prices are given in ascending order.
She read out the names in reverse order.
Then they call out our names in order and we answer yes or no.
order.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: an instruction to do something that is given by someone in authority
order.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: The captain had to give the order to abandon ship.
She is under orders to have a complete rest.
He was thrown into the river on the emperor’s orders.
The company cannot be identified by order of the court.
order.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: a situation in which rules are obeyed and authority is respected
order.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: the breakdown of law and order
The riots are a threat to public order.
The army was called in to restore order.
The physics teacher couldn’t keep order in any class.
She had trouble keeping her teenage sons in order.
order.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: a situation in which everything is controlled, well organized, and correctly arranged
order.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: Let’s have some order in here.
You need to put your financial affairs in order.
She keeps her room in good order.
order.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: a request for food or drink in a restaurant or bar
order.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: the food or drink you have asked for in a restaurant or bar
order.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: When our order finally arrived we were very hungry indeed.
order.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: a request by a customer for a company to supply goods
order.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: Goods will be sent within 24 hours of receiving your order.
You can always cancel your order if you change your mind.
The government has placed an order for (=asked a company to supply) new weapons.
Please complete the enclosed order form.
They make hand-made shoes to order.
order.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: goods that you have ordered from a company
order.translation[0].definitions[9].exam: Your order has arrived – you can collect it from the store any time.
order.translation[0].definitions[10].def: the political, social, or economic situation at a particular time
order.translation[0].definitions[10].exa: The people of South Africa wanted a new order.
He dared to challenge the established (=traditional) order.
He called the rioters a threat to the social order.
order.translation[0].definitions[11].def: a society of monks or nuns (=people who live a holy life according to religious rules)
order.translation[0].definitions[12].def: an organization or a society whose members meet for secret ceremonies
order.translation[0].definitions[13].def: a group of people who have received a special official reward from a king, president etc for their services or achievements
order.translation[0].definitions[14].def: an official piece of paper that can be exchanged for money
order.translation[0].definitions[15].def: a group of animals or plants that are considered together because they evolved from the same plant or animal
order.translation[0].definitions[16].def: a list of jobs that a computer has to do in a particular order
order.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 2: the way that things or events are arranged in relation to each other, so that one thing is first, another thing is second etc
order.translation[0].note_box[0].section: the right/correct order
Of course, the notes must be played in the right order.
the wrong order
The pages had been put in the wrong order.
the same order
He always closed the windows in the same order.
reverse order
They announced the results in reverse order, starting with the last.
alphabetical order
List the names in alphabetical order.
numerical order
The dogs are given numbers, and stand in numerical order while the judge looks at them.
chronological order
The paintings are arranged in chronological order.
ascending/descending order
The films are ranked in ascending order of profitability.
a logical order
Put the events of the story into a logical order.
put/arrange something in order
Decide what points you want to talk about, and put them in order.
in order of importance/priority/preference etc
The country’s main exports were, in order of importance, coffee, sugar, and soya beans.
order.translation[0].note_box[1].heading: – Meaning 3: an instruction to do something that is given by someone in authority
order.translation[0].note_box[1].section: Do not fire until I give the order.
He refused to obey this order.
The men argued that they had only been following orders.
I don’t take orders from you!
Anyone who disobeys these orders will be severely punished.
The soldiers had orders to shoot anyone on the streets after 10 o'clock.
The general says he received no order to withdraw.
The court made an adoption order.
What happens to a soldier who disobeys a direct order?
They had strict orders not to allow anyone through.
Now they’re faced with a court order that could force them to leave.
President Grant issued an executive order establishing a reservation for the Nez Perce Indians.
She was to rest as much as possible on doctor’s orders.
order.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to ask for food or a drink in a restaurant, bar etc
order.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: Anne ordered another glass of wine.
He sat down and ordered a meal.
order.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to ask for goods or services to be supplied
order.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: I’ve ordered a new computer from the supplier.
order.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: to tell someone that they must do something, especially using your official power or authority
order.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: The court ordered his release from prison.
Tom was ordered to pay £300 as compensation.
Her doctor had ordered her to rest for a week.
The soldiers were ordered back to their units.
He ordered that the house be sold.
order.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: to arrange something in an order
order.translation[1].note_box[0].section: to tell someone they must do something
to tell someone that they must do something, using your official power or authority
A policeman ordered him to stop.
He ordered his men to put down their weapons.
‘Don’t move, ’ he ordered.
to say to someone that they must do something
Stop telling me what to do!
The headmaster told me to wait outside his office.
give orders/instructions
to tell someone exactly what they must do
The police chief gave orders to shoot.
The doctor gave instructions that she should rest as much as possible.
command
used about a high-ranking person such as a general, captain, or king ordering someone to do something
The general commanded the troops to fall back.
They believe that the Lord has commanded them to do this.
instruct
to tell someone to do something, especially when you tell them exactly how it should be done
The architect was instructed to keep the plans simple.
She took three tablets every day, as instructed by her doctor.
to give someone an official or legal order to do something
The judge directed the jury to find her not guilty.
subpoena
to officially order someone to appear in a court of law in order to answer questions
Another three of the president’s advisors were subpoenaed.
order.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: a request by a customer for goods or services
order.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: To place your order by telephone, call this number between 8 am and 6 pm.
The company has received an order for 1,500 machines.
It has three firm orders (=definite ones) for its latest twin-jet aircraft.
order.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: goods that someone has ordered from a company
order.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: Your order has arrived - you can collect it from the store any time.
order.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: the number of requests by customers to buy a new product, book, or record before it has been put on sale
order.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: His new album had been released to advance orders in the UK of 100,000.
order.translation[2].definitions[3].defi: if goods are on order, a customer has asked for them but has not yet received them
order.translation[2].definitions[3].exam: America’s airlines alone have more than $130 billion-worth of aircraft on order.
order.translation[2].definitions[4].defi: if something is made or supplied to order, it is made or supplied especially for a particular customer who has asked for it
order.translation[2].definitions[4].exam: Our exclusive conservatories are still handmade to order, using traditional skills.
order.translation[2].definitions[5].defi: an official statement from a court of law or other authority stating that something must be done
order.translation[2].definitions[5].exam: The decision removed a temporary restraining order that prevented the New York Department of Insurance from releasing the reports.
order.translation[2].definitions[6].defi: the condition of goods or property when they are bought or sold
order.translation[2].definitions[6].exam: The documents state the quantity of goods and their apparent order and condition when received.
The property is in good decorative order.
order.translation[2].definitions[7].defi: if equipment, a machine etc is in good working order, it is working well
order.translation[2].definitions[7].exam: Our standards ensure a BMW bought from us is in perfect running order.
order.translation[2].definitions[8].defi: if equipment or a machine is out of order, it is not working
order.translation[2].definitions[8].exam: I tried to ring him yesterday but his phone was out of order.
order.translation[2].definitions[9].defi: the way that several things are arranged, showing which comes first, second etc
order.translation[2].definitions[9].exam: Place the proposals in order of priority.
order.translation[2].definitions[10].def: the arrangement of different subjects for discussion at a meeting
order.translation[2].definitions[10].exa: As clerk to the committee, your main task is to establish the order of business.
order.translation[2].definitions[11].def: the most important thing to be discussed at a meeting or dealt with
order.translation[2].definitions[11].exa: House Democratic leaders plan to make the proposed tax the top order of business when Congress returns.
order.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: to ask a company to supply goods or services
order.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: Dealers have been reluctant to order new cars in the face of weak sales.
You can order computer games or DVDs that aren’t in stock.
order.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: to tell someone to do something, using your authority or power over them
order.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: A federal appeals court in Philadelphia overturned the verdict and ordered a new trial.
Congress has ordered businesses to comply with the new regulations.
